chapter.title: HQL: The Hibernate Query Language
chapter.para: NHibernate is equiped with an extremely powerful query language that (quite intentionally) looks very much like SQL. But don't be fooled by the syntax; HQL is fully object-oriented, understanding notions like inheritence, polymorphism and association.

sect1.title: Case Sensitivity
sect1.para: Queries are case-insensitive, except for names of .NET classes and properties. So SeLeCT is the same as sELEct is the same as SELECT but Eg.FOO is not Eg.Foo and foo.barSet is not foo.BARSET.
This manual uses lowercase HQL keywords. Some users find queries with uppercase keywords more readable, but we find this convention ugly when embedded in Java code.

sect1.title: The from clause
sect1.para: The simplest possible NHibernate query is of the form:
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.Cat
sect1.para: which simply returns all instances of the class Eg.Cat.
Most of the time, you will need to assign an alias, since you will want to refer to the Cat in other parts of the query.
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.Cat as cat
sect1.para: This query assigns the alias cat to Cat instances, so we could use that alias later in the query. The as keyword is optional; we could also write:
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.Cat cat
sect1.para: Multiple classes may appear, resulting in a cartesian product or "cross" join.
sect1.programlisting: from Formula, Parameter
from Formula as form, Parameter as param
sect1.para: It is considered good practice to name query aliases using an initial lowercase, consistent with naming standards for local variables (eg. domesticCat).

sect1.title: Associations and joins
sect1.para: We may also assign aliases to associated entities, or even to elements of a collection of values, using a join.
sect1.programlisting:
from Eg.Cat as cat inner join cat.Mate as mate left outer join cat.Kittens as kitten
from Eg.Cat as cat left join cat.Mate.Kittens as kittens
from Formula form full join form.Parameter param
sect1.para: The supported join types are borrowed from ANSI SQL
The inner join, left outer join and right outer join constructs may be abbreviated.
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.Cat as cat join cat.Mate as mate left join cat.Kittens as kitten
sect1.para: In addition, a "fetch" join allows associations or collections of values to be initialized along with their parent objects, using a single select. This is particularly useful in the case of a collection. It effectively overrides the outer join and lazy declarations of the mapping file for associations and collections. See for more information.
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.Cat as cat inner join fetch cat.Mate left join fetch cat.Kittens
sect1.para: A fetch join does not usually need to assign an alias, because the associated objects should not be used in the where clause (or any other clause). Also, the associated objects are not returned directly in the query results. Instead, they may be accessed via the parent object.

It is possible to create a cartesian product by join fetching more than one collection in a query, so take care in this case. Join fetching multiple collection roles is also disabled for bag mappings. Note also that the fetch construct may not be used in queries called using Enumerable(). Finally, note that full join fetch and right join fetch are not meaningful.

sect1.title: The select clause
sect1.para: The select clause picks which objects and properties to return in the query result set. Consider:
sect1.programlisting: select mate from Eg.Cat as cat inner join cat.Mate as mate
sect1.para: The query will select Mates of other Cats. Actually, you may express this query more compactly as:
sect1.programlisting: select cat.Mate from Eg.Cat cat
sect1.para: You may even select collection elements, using the special elements function. The following query returns all kittens of any cat.
sect1.programlisting: select elements(cat.Kittens) from Eg.Cat cat
sect1.para: Queries may return properties of any value type including properties of component type:
sect1.programlisting:
select cat.Name from Eg.DomesticCat cat where cat.Name like 'fri%'
select cust.Name.FirstName from Customer as cust
sect1.para: Queries may return multiple objects and/or properties as an array of type object[]
sect1.programlisting: select mother, offspr, mate.Name from Eg.DomesticCat as mother inner join mother.Mate as mate left outer join mother.Kittens as offspr
sect1.para: or as an actual typesafe object
sect1.programlisting: select new Family(mother, mate, offspr) from Eg.DomesticCat as mother join mother.Mate as mate left join mother.Kittens as offspr
sect1.para: assuming that the class Family has an appropriate constructor.

sect1.title: Aggregate functions
sect1.para: HQL queries may even return the results of aggregate functions on properties:
sect1.programlisting: select avg(cat.Weight), sum(cat.Weight), max(cat.Weight), count(cat) from Eg.Cat cat
sect1.para: Collections may also appear inside aggregate functions in the select clause.
sect1.programlisting: select cat, count( elements(cat.Kittens) ) from Eg.Cat cat group by cat.Id, cat.Weight, ...
sect1.para: The supported aggregate functions are
The distinct and all keywords may be used and have the same semantics as in SQL.
sect1.programlisting:
select distinct cat.Name from Eg.Cat cat
select count(distinct cat.Name), count(cat) from Eg.Cat cat

sect1.title: Polymorphic queries
sect1.para: A query like:
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.Cat as cat
sect1.para: returns instances not only of Cat, but also of subclasses like DomesticCat. NHibernate queries may name any .NET class or interface in the from clause. The query will return instances of all persistent classes that extend that class or implement the interface. The following query would return all persistent objects:
sect1.programlisting: from System.Object o
sect1.para: The interface INamed might be implemented by various persistent classes:
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.Named n, Eg.Named m where n.Name = m.Name
sect1.para: Note that these last two queries will require more than one SQL SELECT. This means that the order by clause does not correctly order the whole result set.
In order to use non-mapped base classes or interfaces in HQL queries, they have to be imported. See for more information.

sect1.title: The where clause
sect1.para: The where clause allows you to narrow the list of instances returned.
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.Cat as cat where cat.Name='Fritz'
sect1.para: returns instances of Cat named 'Fritz'.
sect1.programlisting: select foo from Eg.Foo foo, Eg.Bar bar where foo.StartDate = bar.Date
sect1.para: will return all instances of Foo for which there exists an instance of Bar with a Date property equal to the StartDate property of the Foo. Compound path expressions make the where clause extremely powerful. Consider:
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.Cat cat where cat.Mate.Name is not null
sect1.para: This query translates to an SQL query with a table (inner) join. If you were to write something like
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.Foo foo where foo.Bar.Baz.Customer.Address.City is not null
sect1.para: you would end up with a query that would require four table joins in SQL.
The = operator may be used to compare not only properties, but also instances:
sect1.programlisting:
from Eg.Cat cat, Eg.Cat rival where cat.Mate = rival.Mate
select cat, mate from Eg.Cat cat, Eg.Cat mate where cat.Mate = mate
sect1.para: The special property (lowercase) id may be used to reference the unique identifier of an object. (You may also use its property name.)
sect1.programlisting:
from Eg.Cat as cat where cat.id = 123
from Eg.Cat as cat where cat.Mate.id = 69
sect1.para: The second query is efficient. No table join is required!
Properties of composite identifiers may also be used. Suppose Person has a composite identifier consisting of Country and MedicareNumber.
sect1.programlisting:
from Bank.Person person where person.id.Country = 'AU' and person.id.MedicareNumber = 123456
from Bank.Account account where account.Owner.id.Country = 'AU' and account.Owner.id.MedicareNumber = 123456
sect1.para: Once again, the second query requires no table join.

Likewise, the special property class accesses the discriminator value of an instance in the case of polymorphic persistence. A Java class name embedded in the where clause will be translated to its discriminator value.
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.Cat cat where cat.class = Eg.DomesticCat
sect1.para: You may also specify properties of components or composite user types (and of components of components, etc). Never try to use a path-expression that ends in a property of component type (as opposed to a property of a component). For example, if store.Owner is an entity with a component Address
sect1.programlisting: store.Owner.Address.City // okay store.Owner.Address // error!
sect1.para: An "any" type has the special properties id and class, allowing us to express a join in the following way (where AuditLog.Item is a property mapped with <any>).
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.AuditLog log, Eg.Payment payment where log.Item.class = 'Eg.Payment, Eg, Version=...' and log.Item.id = payment.id
sect1.para: Notice that log.Item.class and payment.class would refer to the values of completely different database columns in the above query.

sect1.title: Expressions
sect1.para: Expressions allowed in the where clause include most of the kind of things you could write in SQL:

listitem.para: SQL scalar functions like upper() and lower()

sect1.para: in and between may be used as follows:
sect1.programlisting:
from Eg.DomesticCat cat where cat.Name between 'A' and 'B'
from Eg.DomesticCat cat where cat.Name in ( 'Foo', 'Bar', 'Baz' )
sect1.para: and the negated forms may be written
sect1.programlisting:
from Eg.DomesticCat cat where cat.Name not between 'A' and 'B'
from Eg.DomesticCat cat where cat.Name not in ( 'Foo', 'Bar', 'Baz' )
sect1.para: Likewise, is null and is not null may be used to test for null values.
Booleans may be easily used in expressions by declaring HQL query substitutions in NHibernate configuration:
sect1.programlisting: <property name="hibernate.query.substitutions">true 1, false 0</property>
sect1.para: This will replace the keywords true and false with the literals 1 and 0 in the translated SQL from this HQL:
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.Cat cat where cat.Alive = true
sect1.para: You may test the size of a collection with the special property size, or the special size() function.
sect1.programlisting:
from Eg.Cat cat where cat.Kittens.size > 0
from Eg.Cat cat where size(cat.Kittens) > 0
sect1.para: For indexed collections, you may refer to the minimum and maximum indices using minIndex and maxIndex. Similarly, you may refer to the minimum and maximum elements of a collection of basic type using minElement and maxElement.
sect1.programlisting: from Calendar cal where cal.Holidays.maxElement > current date
sect1.para: There are also functional forms (which, unlike the constructs above, are not case sensitive):
sect1.programlisting:
from Order order where maxindex(order.Items) > 100
from Order order where minelement(order.Items) > 10000
sect1.para: The SQL functions any, some, all, exists, in are supported when passed the element or index set of a collection (elements and indices functions) or the result of a subquery (see below).
Note that these constructs - size, elements, indices, minIndex, maxIndex, minElement, maxElement - have certain usage restrictions:

listitem.para: in a where clause: only for databases with subselects
in a select clause: only elements and indices make sense

sect1.para: Elements of indexed collections (arrays, lists, maps) may be referred to by index (in a where clause only):
sect1.programlisting:
from Order order where order.Items[0].id = 1234
select person from Person person, Calendar calendar where calendar.Holidays['national day'] = person.BirthDay and person.Nationality.Calendar = calendar
select item from Item item, Order order where order.Items[ order.DeliveredItemIndices[0] ] = item and order.id = 11
select item from Item item, Order order where order.Items[ maxindex(order.items) ] = item and order.id = 11
sect1.para: The expression inside [] may even be an arithmetic expression.
sect1.programlisting: select item from Item item, Order order where order.Items[ size(order.Items) - 1 ] = item
sect1.para: HQL also provides the built-in index() function, for elements of a one-to-many association or collection of values.
sect1.programlisting: select item, index(item) from Order order join order.Items item where index(item) < 5
sect1.para: Scalar SQL functions supported by the underlying database may be used
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.DomesticCat cat where upper(cat.Name) like 'FRI%'
sect1.para: If you are not yet convinced by all this, think how much longer and less readable the following query would be in SQL:
sect1.programlisting: select cust from Product prod, Store store inner join store.Customers cust where prod.Name = 'widget' and store.Location.Name in ( 'Melbourne', 'Sydney' ) and prod = all elements(cust.CurrentOrder.LineItems)
sect1.para: Hint: something like
sect1.programlisting: SELECT cust.name, cust.address, cust.phone, cust.id, cust.current_order FROM customers cust, stores store, locations loc, store_customers sc, product prod WHERE prod.name = 'widget' AND store.loc_id = loc.id AND loc.name IN ( 'Melbourne', 'Sydney' ) AND sc.store_id = store.id AND sc.cust_id = cust.id AND prod.id = ALL( SELECT item.prod_id FROM line_items item, orders o WHERE item.order_id = o.id AND cust.current_order = o.id )

sect1.title: The order by clause
sect1.para: The list returned by a query may be ordered by any property of a returned class or components:
sect1.programlisting: from Eg.DomesticCat cat order by cat.Name asc, cat.Weight desc, cat.Birthdate
sect1.para: The optional asc or desc indicate ascending or descending order respectively.

sect1.title: The group by clause
sect1.para: A query that returns aggregate values may be grouped by any property of a returned class or components:
sect1.programlisting:
select cat.Color, sum(cat.Weight), count(cat) from Eg.Cat cat group by cat.Color
select foo.id, avg( elements(foo.Names) ), max( indices(foo.Names) ) from Eg.Foo foo group by foo.id
sect1.para: Note: You may use the elements and indices constructs inside a select clause, even on databases with no subselects.
A having clause is also allowed.
sect1.programlisting: select cat.color, sum(cat.Weight), count(cat) from Eg.Cat cat group by cat.Color having cat.Color in (Eg.Color.Tabby, Eg.Color.Black)
sect1.para: SQL functions and aggregate functions are allowed in the having and order by clauses, if supported by the underlying database (ie. not in MySQL).
sect1.programlisting: select cat from Eg.Cat cat join cat.Kittens kitten group by cat.Id, cat.Name, cat.Other, cat.Properties having avg(kitten.Weight) > 100 order by count(kitten) asc, sum(kitten.Weight) desc
sect1.para: Note that neither the group by clause nor the order by clause may contain arithmetic expressions. Also note that NHibernate currently does not expand a grouped entity, so you can't write group by cat if all properties of cat are non-aggregated. You have to list all non-aggregated properties explicitly.

sect1.title: Subqueries
sect1.para: For databases that support subselects, NHibernate supports subqueries within queries. A subquery must be surrounded by parentheses (often by an SQL aggregate function call). Even correlated subqueries (subqueries that refer to an alias in the outer query) are allowed.

sect1.title: HQL examples
sect1.para: NHibernate queries can be quite powerful and complex. In fact, the power of the query language is one of NHibernate's main selling points. Here are some example queries very similar to queries that I used on a recent project. Note that most queries you will write are much simpler than these!

The following query returns the order id, number of items and total value of the order for all unpaid orders for a particular customer and given minimum total value, ordering the results by total value. In determining the prices, it uses the current catalog. The resulting SQL query, against the ORDER, ORDER_LINE, PRODUCT, CATALOG and PRICE tables has four inner joins and an (uncorrelated) subselect.
sect1.programlisting: select order.id, sum(price.Amount), count(item) from Order as order join order.LineItems as item join item.Product as product, Catalog as catalog join catalog.Prices as price where order.Paid = false and order.Customer = :customer and price.Product = product and catalog.EffectiveDate < sysdate and catalog.EffectiveDate >= all ( select cat.EffectiveDate from Catalog as cat where cat.EffectiveDate < sysdate ) group by order having sum(price.Amount) > :minAmount order by sum(price.Amount) desc
sect1.para: What a monster! Actually, in real life, I'm not very keen on subqueries, so my query was really more like this:
sect1.programlisting: select order.id, sum(price.amount), count(item) from Order as order join order.LineItems as item join item.Product as product, Catalog as catalog join catalog.Prices as price where order.Paid = false and order.Customer = :customer and price.Product = product and catalog = :currentCatalog group by order having sum(price.Amount) > :minAmount order by sum(price.Amount) desc
sect1.para: The next query counts the number of payments in each status, excluding all payments in the AwaitingApproval status where the most recent status change was made by the current user. It translates to an SQL query with two inner joins and a correlated subselect against the PAYMENT, PAYMENT_STATUS and PAYMENT_STATUS_CHANGE tables.
sect1.programlisting: select count(payment), status.Name from Payment as payment join payment.CurrentStatus as status join payment.StatusChanges as statusChange where payment.Status.Name <> PaymentStatus.AwaitingApproval or ( statusChange.TimeStamp = ( select max(change.TimeStamp) from PaymentStatusChange change where change.Payment = payment ) and statusChange.User <> :currentUser ) group by status.Name, status.SortOrder order by status.SortOrder
sect1.para: If I would have mapped the StatusChanges collection as a list, instead of a set, the query would have been much simpler to write.
sect1.programlisting: select count(payment), status.Name from Payment as payment join payment.CurrentStatus as status where payment.Status.Name <> PaymentStatus.AwaitingApproval or payment.StatusChanges[ maxIndex(payment.StatusChanges) ].User <> :currentUser group by status.Name, status.SortOrder order by status.SortOrder
sect1.para: The next query uses the MS SQL Server isNull() function to return all the accounts and unpaid payments for the organization to which the current user belongs. It translates to an SQL query with three inner joins, an outer join and a subselect against the ACCOUNT, PAYMENT, PAYMENT_STATUS, ACCOUNT_TYPE, ORGANIZATION and ORG_USER tables.
sect1.programlisting: select account, payment from Account as account left outer join account.Payments as payment where :currentUser in elements(account.Holder.Users) and PaymentStatus.Unpaid = isNull(payment.CurrentStatus.Name, PaymentStatus.Unpaid) order by account.Type.SortOrder, account.AccountNumber, payment.DueDate
sect1.para: For some databases, we would need to do away with the (correlated) subselect.
sect1.programlisting: select account, payment from Account as account join account.Holder.Users as user left outer join account.Payments as payment where :currentUser = user and PaymentStatus.Unpaid = isNull(payment.CurrentStatus.Name, PaymentStatus.Unpaid) order by account.Type.SortOrder, account.AccountNumber, payment.DueDate

sect1.title: Tips & Tricks
sect1.para: You can count the number of query results without actually returning them:
sect1.programlisting: int count = (int) session.CreateQuery("select count(*) from ....").UniqueResult();
sect1.para: To order a result by the size of a collection, use the following query:
sect1.programlisting: select usr.id, usr.Name from User as usr left join usr.Messages as msg group by usr.id, usr.Name order by count(msg)
sect1.para: If your database supports subselects, you can place a condition upon selection size in the where clause of your query:
sect1.programlisting: from User usr where size(usr.Messages) >= 1
sect1.para: If your database doesn't support subselects, use the following query:
sect1.programlisting: select usr.id, usr.Name from User usr join usr.Messages msg group by usr.id, usr.Name having count(msg) >= 1
sect1.para: As this solution can't return a User with zero messages because of the inner join, the following form is also useful:
sect1.programlisting: select usr.id, usr.Name from User as usr left join usr.Messages as msg group by usr.id, usr.Name having count(msg) = 0

Collections are pageable by using the IQuery interface with a filter:
Collection elements may be ordered or grouped using a query filter:
sect1.programlisting: ICollection orderedCollection = s.Filter( collection, "order by this.Amount" ); ICollection counts = s.Filter( collection, "select this.Type, count(this) group by this.Type" );
